item.title: Requirements
item.description: Requirements # 1. Server # The server component of Homechart is written in Go and has very low resource requirements: 1 CPU 512MB RAM 2. Database # Homechart requires full access to a PostgreSQL 14 database. Older or newer versions may work, but they are not tested. You can create a database for Homechart on an existing PostgreSQL server with these commands, replacing the database name, username and password:

Binary Install # Homechart can be deployed as a standalone binary on Linux (amd64 and arm) from our releases website. 1. Review the requirements # Ensure your system meets the Server Requirements. 2. Download Homechart # Visit https://releases.homechart.app/ and download the version of Homechart for your platform. Optionally, you can verify your download by comparing the SHA-512 sum: $ sha256sum -c homechart_latest_linux_amd64.gz.sha256 Once your download has completed, decompress it:

Container Install # Homechart can be deployed as a container on Linux (amd64 and arm) from our images hosted on DockerHub. 1. Review the requirements # Ensure your system meets the Server Requirements. 2. Install a container runtime # Homechart can run on any OCI compatible runtime on Linux amd64 and arm64. Most users use Docker and Docker Compose, but we also support Kubernetes and Podman. 3. Run Homechart # The Homechart container is configured to start Homechart server without having to specify a command or entrypoint.

Configuration Options # Homechart can be configured using environment variables or a JSON configuration file. The configuration is divided into sections: App App PostgreSQL SMTP Vault For environment variables, every configuration key can be set using HOMECHART_<SECTION>_<KEY>=a value, i.e. HOMECHART_CLI_DEBUG=true For a JSON or YAML configuration file, the keys are camelCase and nested under each section: JSON { "app": { "baseURL": "example.com" } } YAML app: baseURL: example.com Configuration values can be booleans (true/false), integers (1/2/3), lists (1,2,3/a,b,c), and strings (a/b/c).
